article: My mother knew that she could not send me to college and pay for it.If I wanted to go to college, it was up to roe to find out how to get there.I found that I _ for some grants .There was enough to _ school and books, but not enough for room and board.I accepted a job as part of a work-study program.I washed dishes in the school cafeteria.My grades went up and down .It was the hardest work I had _ done. Just when I thought I was going to drop out of my college career, a friend told me that his grandmother needed help on the weekends. _ that was required of me was cooking meals. Now I would have time to study.I went to meet his grandmother and accepted the job.My first _ was his grandmother' s great love of music.One day, she told me I didn't have enough _ .Grandma was _ with my ability and encouraged me to continue.Weekends became more than just books and cooking; they were filled with the wonderful sounds of the piano and two singers. When Christmas break came, Grandma got a chest cold _ I was unwilling to leave her.I hadn't been home since Labor Day, and my family was _ to see me.I said my good-bye, _ for her temporary care and returned home. _ I was loading my car to go back to school, the phone rang and my friend told me Grandma died.I hung up the phone feeling like my world had ended.I had _ my friend, and that was _ worse than knowing I would have to return to dishwashing. Four weeks later, I asked to begin the work-study program again.The financial aid advisor looked at me as if I had lost my mind.I _ my position, then he smiled and slid me an envelope which was from Grandma.She had known how sick she was.In the envelope was enough money to pay for the rest of my school year and a request that I take piano lessons in her _ . Now, years later, when I walk by a piano, I _ and think of Grandma.She is playing the piano in heaven, I am sure.
